user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Console_CopyOut:
```c
static int32 OS_Console_CopyOut(OS_console_internal_record_t *console, const char *Str, size_t *NextWritePos)
{
    const char *pmsg;
    size_t      WriteOffset;
    int32       return_code;

    return_code = OS_ERROR;
    pmsg        = Str;
    WriteOffset = *NextWritePos;
    while (true)
    {
        if (*pmsg == 0)
        {
            /* String is complete */
            *NextWritePos = WriteOffset;
            return_code   = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }
        console->BufBase[WriteOffset] = *pmsg;
        WriteOffset                   = WriteOffset + 1;
        if (WriteOffset >= console->BufSize)
        {
            WriteOffset = 0;
        }

        if (WriteOffset == console->ReadPos)
        {
            /* out of space */
            return_code = OS_QUEUE_FULL;
            break;
        }

        ++pmsg;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter pointer is modified in this function. The parameters are: console (OS_console_internal_record_t *), Str (const char *), and NextWritePos (size_t *). The code does not assign to any of these parameter variables themselves — there are no statements like console = ..., Str = ..., or NextWritePos = ....

Only the objects pointed to by pointer parameters are modified, which is allowed by the rule: console->BufBase[WriteOffset] = *pmsg; and *NextWritePos = WriteOffset; The initial read WriteOffset = *NextWritePos; only reads the pointed object. The local pointer pmsg is assigned from Str and incremented (++pmsg); because pmsg is a local variable (not a parameter), modifying it does not violate Rule 17.8.

Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in this function.
